title: Bank Heavyweights Help Financial ETF Set Record
sub_head: Flows of $3.6 billion so far in January into the Financial Select Sector SPDR exchange-traded fund already exceed every full-month total since November 2016
body:
The U.S. stock market’s most popular financial services exchange-traded fund is hovering near an all-time high for the first time since the onset of the Covid-19 pandemic, propelled by a handful of big stocks.
The which has roughly $30 billion in assets and tracks the S&P 500’s financial sector, reached $31.46 a share last week, eclipsing its February 2020 high. Shares traded just below $31 on Wednesday.
ETFs tracking the S&P 500’s technology, communication, consumer-discretionary and health-care sectors surpassed their pre-Covid-19 highs last year. But many cyclical groups, including financials, had lagged behind the broader stock market’s recovery as investors favored buying shares of fast-growing companies. Since the November elections, though, the investment tides have shifted toward economically sensitive companies amid expectations of heavy spending by Democrats, which investors expect will help boost growth.
Investors have sought to increase their exposure to bank stocks by putting money into the Financial Select Sector ETF for 11 straight weeks. Flows so far in January have reached $3.6 billion, already exceeding every full-month total since November 2016, according to data from Refinitiv Lipper.
But some investors might not realize that the ETF is essentially a wager on the success of a few of the biggest financial stocks in the S&P 500. JPMorgan Chase & Co. and Berkshire Hathaway Inc. account for about a quarter of the fund, while the addition of Bank of America Corp. increases the collective weighting of the three stocks to roughly 33%. It is no surprise then that the ETF’s return to record levels coincided with a rally in those stocks.
